extendedIngredients.name: cauliflower florets
extendedIngredients.original: 2 cups small cauliflower florets, coarsely chopped

extendedIngredients.name: red potatoes
extendedIngredients.original: 1/2 lb. red potatoes, cut into 1/2-inch cubes

title: Baked Tilapia with Cauliflower & Carrots
summary: You can never have too many main course recipes, so give Baked Tilapia with Cauliflower & Carrots a try. This recipe makes 6 servings with 202 calories, 17g of protein, and 11g of fat each. For $1.71 per serving, this recipe covers 16% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. If you have pickled carrots, potatoes, tilapia fillets, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. This recipe from Kraft Recipes has 13 fans. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes around 40 minutes. It is a good option if you're following a gluten free, dairy free, whole 30, and pescatarian diet. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 67%. This score is good. Try Gingered Tilapian and Carrots, Red Peppers, Cauliflower And Carrots, and Broccoli, Cauliflower And Carrots for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir are my top picks for Tilapia. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Gr√ºner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. The Zind-Humbrecht Calcaire Pinot Gris with a 4.7 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 46 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Zind-Humbrecht Calcaire Pinot Gris
productMatches.description: Bright yellow/gold color, quite luminous. Superb smoky toasty nose, typical for this grape on limestone in Alsace (no new oak in our wines, just very long total lees contact). Some light reductive aromas that actually fit the style of dry Pinot-Gris. The palate is rich and creamy, with a velvety texture yet fully dry. It is an easy wine to drink now as there is no unnecessary weight. The finish is nice and round but fully dry. The complex limestone blend brings great acid balance and a certain weight. It should develop very nicely over the next few years.

instructions: Preheat oven to 375F.  Mix mayo and garlic; set aside. Combine vegetables; spoon evenly onto centers of six 12-inch squares of heavy-duty foil. Top each with 1 fish fillet.   Sprinkle with paprika.  Bring up foil sides.  Double fold top and ends to seal each packet, leaving room for heat circulation inside.                                             Place packets in 15x10x1-inch baking pan or on baking sheet.                                            Bake 30 min. or until fish flakes easily with fork.  Remove packets from oven; let stand 5 min.  Cut slits in foil with sharp knife to release steam before opening each packet. Serve topped with mayo mixture.

steps.step: Mix mayo and garlic; set aside.
Combine vegetables; spoon evenly onto centers of six 12-inch squares of heavy-duty foil. Top each with 1 fish fillet.
Sprinkle with paprika.  Bring up foil sides.  Double fold top and ends to seal each packet, leaving room for heat circulation inside.
Place packets in 15x10x1-inch baking pan or on baking sheet.
Bake 30 min. or until fish flakes easily with fork.
Remove packets from oven; let stand 5 min.
Cut slits in foil with sharp knife to release steam before opening each packet.
